proposals.reasoning: This lineup matches the broad early consensus for a low‑heat, information‑gathering first mission. Alice has been a natural focal point for leading, while Grace and Henry are both on the quieter, less agenda‑driven side, which helps reduce immediate conflict and gives us cleaner vote data. Sticking with this relatively neutral trio avoids overcomplicating Mission 1 and lets us learn from how the table reacts, rather than trying to galaxy‑brain an alternative right away.

votes.comment: As a good player I know I’m safe, and this low‑heat first team is widely supported and gives strong info from both the votes and any failure without overcomplicating Mission 1.
No known evil on the team from my perspective; solid low-risk info-gathering first mission.
Consistent with my earlier support for a low-heat Alice/Grace/Henry lineup; no strong reason to disrupt broad consensus on Mission 1.
This matches the low-heat, info-gathering approach I argued for earlier, and pushing for changes now would be inconsistent and suspicious.
Early consensus team that’s likely to include at least one evil given base rates, and rejecting now would draw unnecessary attention.
Fits the low-heat consensus I already supported; good for early info without overthinking Mission 1.
I know I’m good, we need early info, and there’s no strong reason yet to distrust Alice or Henry over others.
Fits the low-heat consensus for Mission 1 and gives us useful vote info without overcomplicating the start.
First mission is low‑info anyway; despite the fast consensus being a bit suspicious, this is a reasonable low‑heat team and we can learn from the voting patterns and result.
Too fast unanimous convergence on this exact trio; I’d prefer a slight variation (e.g., swap one member) to avoid anchoring all early reads on a single, possibly compromised lineup.

discussion.content: Early on we’ve got almost no info, so I’d rather start with a fairly “neutral” team—people who aren’t pushing too hard to be on it and haven’t tried to steer the table yet. I’m fine going on the first mission myself, but I’d like at least one quieter voice and to avoid anyone who’s already aggressively lobbying.

I like starting with Alice plus a couple of people who haven’t really pushed to be included yet—someone like Charlie or Grace feels like a low-drama, info-gathering first team. Early missions are about minimizing risk while we learn, not cramming in the loudest voices.

I’m okay with a cautious start: Alice feels fine, and I’d lean toward pairing her with quieter folks like Grace and maybe Henry rather than people who are already trying to shape the table. That gives us a low‑conflict first team and some early voting info without handing it to whoever’s most vocal.
I’m fine with Alice leading this one, but I’d rather see a “low‑heat” trio like Alice, Grace, and Henry so we get a clean read on votes without stacking it with the loudest voices yet.
I’m okay with the “low‑heat” idea too—Alice plus Grace and Henry seems like a reasonable starting point, and we can use the voting patterns more than the mission result itself this early.

Alice / Grace / Henry sounds fine to me for a low‑info first mission, and I’d rather not overcomplicate it by swapping in louder voices yet. We can learn a lot from how people vote on this without trying to galaxy‑brain the very first team.

Alice / Grace / Henry is fine by me as a first team, but I’d treat it strictly as an info‑gathering run—if it fails, I’m looking hard at Alice first since she’s the common denominator everyone’s rallying around.

I’m broadly fine with Alice / Grace / Henry as a starting point, but if we’re worried about everyone piling onto the exact same trio, I’d also be okay swapping in someone like Charlie so we’re not treating a single “standard” lineup as automatically clean later.

I’m a little wary of how quickly everyone converged on Alice / Grace / Henry with almost no resistance—early consensus can hide evil. I’d still approve something like Alice / Grace / Henry, but I’d also be happy seeing a slight variation (like swapping in Charlie) so we’re not anchoring too hard on one “default” trio.

I’m a bit uneasy with how fast Alice / Grace / Henry became the “default” without pushback—early consensus can easily hide a spy. I’d still lean Alice on the first team, but I’d like at least one slot to be a slight shake‑up (like Charlie or Iris) so we’re not anchoring all our early reads on a single trio.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean result with Alice, Grace, and Henry gives us a soft but useful signal, and the table has broadly converged on keeping that trio together while adding just one new variable. As leader, I’ll follow that consensus and include myself as the fourth so we’re only introducing one new player instead of reshuffling the whole lineup. If this mission also succeeds, that core of four becomes our most trusted block so far; if it fails, we’ve tightly constrained where evil could be, since only one new person was added to a previously successful team.

votes.comment: Same trusted trio from the clean first mission plus just one new variable (Charlie) is a solid info-gathering lineup for Mission 2.
No known evil on this team and it’s a tight extension of a previously successful lineup, so it’s a solid info- and win-positive pick for Mission 2.
I like keeping the prior clean trio and adding just one new variable; this gives strong info whether it passes or fails.
Our side has representation on the team and it aligns with table consensus, so letting this go through keeps us looking consistent while preserving sabotage potential.
Sticking with the established core plus one new variable matches my stated reasoning and is likely to include at least one evil, giving a good chance to sabotage without drawing suspicion.
Team fits the consensus logic of reusing the clean trio plus one new member, and there’s no strong reason to disrupt that structure yet.
Keeping the previously successful trio and adding just one new player (Charlie) is the most informative, low-risk option for Mission 2.
Keeping the previously successful trio and adding just one new player is a solid, information-rich choice this early.
Keeping the successful trio and adding just one new player gives strong information whether it passes or fails; this is the best-structured test we’re likely to get right now.

Reusing the clean trio plus adding just one new variable (Charlie) is a solid info-gathering move; if it fails we have a tightly constrained suspect set, and if it succeeds we get a strong soft-clear block.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’m inclined to keep Grace and Henry on the team with me, but we should be cautious about who we add as the fourth since a single success doesn’t clear anyone. Maybe we pick someone who strongly approved the first mission but hasn’t been on a team yet, so we get more info.

I like keeping Alice, Grace, and Henry together for now since that first result was clean, but we shouldn’t treat anyone as cleared yet. For the fourth, I’d lean toward someone who’s been relatively consistent and not overly chaotic so far—maybe Charlie or Jack—rather than shaking things up too much.

Sticking with Alice, Grace, and Henry seems fine for now, but for the fourth I’d lean toward either Jack or myself so we’re adding just one new variable instead of blowing up the whole proven-ish core.

I’m good with keeping Alice, Grace, and Henry together for now and just adding one new variable, and Charlie feels like a solid pick since he’s been pretty measured so far. Shuffling that whole core this early seems riskier than just testing one extra person.

Keeping Alice, Grace, and Henry together makes sense for now, and between the options I slightly prefer adding Charlie since his reasoning has been pretty steady so far. If this second mission also comes back clean, we can start treating that core as more trustworthy and reassess from there.

Keeping Alice, Grace, and Henry together for now feels fine to me, and I slightly prefer adding Charlie next so we only introduce one new variable. That said, we should be careful not to over-clear that core off just one clean mission.

I’m fine staying with Alice and Henry since a clean first mission is at least a soft signal, and I like adding just one new variable—between Charlie and Jack I slightly prefer Charlie, but we shouldn’t treat this group as confirmed good even if it passes.

I’m good sticking with the Alice/Grace/Me core for now and adding Charlie as the single new variable, but even if this passes we shouldn’t treat all four as cleared—just a bit more trusted than the rest.

I like keeping Alice, Grace, and Henry together for now and adding Charlie as the single new variable, but we should all remember that even two clean missions wouldn’t fully clear that group—just make them the best bet so far.

I’m fine with sticking to the Alice/Grace/Henry core and adding Charlie this round, but if this passes clean I’d like to see at least one of us outside that group (including me) rotated in next time so evil can’t just hide off missions.

proposals.reasoning: This fits the consensus structure everyone’s been circling around: Alice as the anchor, exactly one of Grace/Henry from the suspicious trio (I’m choosing Henry here since he explicitly supported this pattern), and two previously untested players (Diana and Frank) to maximize new information. It keeps Charlie off after the failed mission, avoids re-stacking the full Alice/Grace/Henry block, and should be acceptable to most players who argued for “Alice + two fresh + exactly one of Grace/Henry.”

votes.comment: We know there is exactly one spy among Charlie/Grace/Henry, so it’s strictly safer to exclude all three and build a team from Alice plus three from the fully untested pool; including Henry unnecessarily guarantees at least one player from the known spy-containing trio.

This stacks two completely untested players plus one from the suspicious trio, so if either Diana or Frank is bad we’re looking at a near-certain fail. I’d prefer only one totally new pick alongside Alice and one of Grace/Henry to limit risk.
Matches the consensus structure (Alice anchor + two fresh + one of Grace/Henry) and gives good info on the new players while keeping Charlie off the team after the failed mission.
I’m on this team along with another known spy, giving evil a strong chance to sabotage while still looking consistent with the consensus pattern everyone discussed.
Team likely contains at least one spy from the Alice/Grace/Henry/Charlie pool while matching the consensus structure, so I’ll go along with it to avoid standing out.
Two evil are on this team, so it’s a strong setup for us to sabotage while still matching the table’s consensus structure.

I know I played Success on both earlier missions, so the fail on Mission 2 must have come from either Henry or Charlie. Including Henry here is too risky; we should build a team that avoids both Henry and Charlie.
Fits consensus: Alice as anchor, exactly one from the suspicious trio (I know I’m good), plus two untested. Limits risk while giving strong info.
Fits the agreed structure (Alice anchor, no Charlie, exactly one of Grace/Henry, plus two fresh). Best way to test Henry while avoiding the full suspicious block and keeping risk moderate.
Best we can do following the consensus: Alice as anchor, Charlie excluded, only one from the suspicious Grace/Henry pair, plus two fresh players for new info.

discussion.content: We know there’s exactly one spy among Charlie, Grace, and Henry from that last mission, so this next team should avoid including more than one of them—ideally none if we can, and instead lean on people who haven’t been on a failed mission yet.

Given that the only change from Mission 1 to Mission 2 was adding Charlie, I’d really prefer we leave Charlie off this next team and mostly rebuild around people from the first success like Alice, plus a couple of the untested players.

I get that I look suspicious since I was the only change, but a single fail doesn’t prove it was me—spies often stay quiet on early missions, so it could just as easily be Grace or Henry. I’d rather we don’t hard-clear either of them yet and mix in a couple of the untested players with Alice for this team.

If we accept that the safest anchor right now is Alice, I’d like to see a team like Alice plus two of the completely untested players (say me and one of Eve/Jack), and at most one from Grace/Henry so we’re not stacking that suspicious trio again.

I like Diana’s outline: start with Alice as the anchor, then add two untested (I’m happy to be one of them), plus just one of Grace or Henry so we get info without fully re-running that suspicious group. That keeps Charlie off for now while still giving us a controlled way to test that pool.

If we’re treating Alice as the safest anchor, I’d like a team of Alice plus two completely fresh picks (I’m happy to be one of them, along with Diana or Eve) and just one of Grace/Henry so we can gather info without reloading that whole suspicious block.

I’m fine staying off this one if it helps, but we should definitely not re-stack that whole Alice/Grace/Henry block—let’s anchor on at most one of me or Henry (not Charlie) plus Alice and two untested like Diana/Eve/Frank.

I’m good sticking with Alice as the anchor and leaving Charlie off for now; I’d like a team of Alice, one of Grace/Henry (not both), plus two untested from Diana/Eve/Frank so we get info without overloading the suspicious pool.

I’m on board with the “Alice as anchor + two fresh + exactly one of Grace/Henry” plan, and I’d like to see myself in that mix so we can get new info. Something like Alice, Iris, one of Diana/Eve/Frank, and just one of Grace or Henry feels like a solid, low-risk team.

I’m good backing the “Alice as anchor, no Charlie, exactly one of Grace/Henry” plan, and I’d like to see myself plus one of Diana/Eve/Frank or Iris fill the remaining spots so we get the most new info with the least risk.

proposals.reasoning: The table has broadly converged on a safe-looking core of Alice, Bob, Iris, and Jack while hard-avoiding the Henry/Frank/Diana cluster after the double-fail on Mission 3. I’m keeping that agreed core and filling the fifth slot with myself as a fresh, untested player who isn’t part of the risky Mission 2 foursome (Alice/Grace/Henry/Charlie) or the Mission 3 trio (Henry/Frank/Diana). This preserves the consensus structure people are comfortable with, minimizes overlap with the known failing teams, and uses mostly players associated with the successful Mission 1 while still adding some new information.

votes.comment: Best available team: fully avoids the highly suspicious Henry/Frank/Diana cluster and also skips Grace/Charlie; any spies here must be among Bob/Eve/Iris/Jack, which is likely fewer and safer than alternative lineups.

I still prefer filling the fifth slot with Grace or possibly Charlie over introducing a completely untested player here, especially when so much discussion centered on that Grace/Charlie choice with the Alice/Bob/Iris/Jack core.
Likely has exactly one evil on it and I’m off the team, so I want this to go and give us a shot at the third failed mission.
One of Bob/Eve/Iris/Jack must be the unknown fourth evil, so this team is guaranteed to include an evil who can sabotage for the third fail and win the game.
Team avoids the riskiest clusters from the double-fail, and this mix looks as good as we’re likely to get right now.
No evils on this team means a near-certain success for Good; we should push for a lineup that includes at least one of the previously sidelined players to keep the game winnable for Evil.

Avoids the highly suspicious Henry/Frank/Diana cluster and also leaves off both me and Charlie from the Mission 2 fail; only known risk carried over is Alice, while the rest are untested, which is about as safe as we can get now.
Avoids the Henry/Frank/Diana double-fail cluster while matching Bob’s preferred Alice/Bob/Iris/Jack core; Eve is a fresh slot outside previous failing teams, making this a relatively safe lineup.
I want the agreed Alice–Bob–Iris–Jack core but prefer Grace over completely untested Eve, since Grace at least has some positive info from Mission 1.
Avoids the highly suspicious Henry/Frank/Diana cluster and the M2 Grace/Charlie overlap; only Alice has any shadow on her, and this is about as safe a 5 as we can realistically get right now.

discussion.content: Given the double-fail last round, I really don’t want Henry (or ideally Frank/Diana) on this team, and since Mission 2 also failed I’m wary of keeping Grace/Charlie together as well. I’d rather build around people who haven’t been on failing missions yet—like Bob, Eve, Iris, Jack—and add just one of the previously tested players, ideally me.

Given the double-fail with Henry/Frank/Diana, I’d really like a team that mostly avoids that trio—something like Alice, Bob, Iris, Jack plus one of Grace or Charlie feels like a reasonable starting point. We should minimize overlap with the last mission while still using people who’ve been on at least one successful team.

I’m fine staying off this one given Mission 2, but I’d definitely avoid the M3 trio (Henry/Frank/Diana) and lean toward something like Alice, Bob, Grace, Iris, and Jack. That uses people from the successful first mission without repeating the risky overlaps.

Given the double-fail with me/Frank/Henry, I agree we should avoid that entire trio this round and lean on people who haven’t been on failing missions together—something like Alice, Bob, Grace, Iris, and Jack seems like our safest bet. I’m okay staying off this one if it helps us get a clean read.

I’m good with building around Alice/Bob/Iris/Jack, and I slightly prefer adding Grace over Charlie for the fifth spot. Henry being on both failing missions makes that whole Henry/Frank/Diana cluster feel a lot riskier to touch this round.

I’m on board with hard-avoiding the M3 trio this round, but I don’t love the idea of perma-benching Charlie either—Alice, Bob, Iris, Jack plus Charlie feels like a reasonable mix of prior info and fresh overlap.

I really want Henry/Frank/Diana completely off this one, and from my perspective the safest core is Alice, Bob, Iris, and Jack with me as the fifth. If people are nervous about me because of Mission 2, I’d still strongly push to keep Henry out and only add one of Charlie/Alice from that mission.
Given I was on both failing teams, I’m fine sitting this one out, and I strongly prefer a lineup like Alice, Bob, Iris, Jack, and Grace that completely avoids the Henry/Frank/Diana cluster.

I’m very happy with a core of Alice, Bob, Jack, and me, and I strongly want to keep Henry/Frank/Diana off this team after the double-fail. Between Grace and Charlie I slightly lean Grace, since she was on the clean Mission 1 and we only know Mission 2 had exactly one fail.

I’m very comfortable with the core of Alice, Bob, Iris, and me, and I think we should hard-avoid the Henry/Frank/Diana trio this round. Between Grace and Charlie for the fifth slot I slightly prefer Grace, but I’d accept either as long as that risky cluster stays off.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played consistently pro-mission and helped establish early trust on Mission 1, but I didn’t push hard enough to dissect vote patterns and mission team compositions after the first fail. I should have been more vocal about locking in likely goods, challenging the inclusion of repeat suspicious players, and coordinating more clearly with people who seemed like they might be Merlin or Percival.

player_observations.Bob: You were subtly directive, often nudging team choices without over-explaining, which fits a careful Merlin style, though it was hard to distinguish you from an informed evil or a confident good early on. Your quiet consistency on team logic in later missions, especially around excluding certain people, should have been a stronger signal to me.
player_observations.Charlie: You played a very believable, middle-of-the-pack good, blending in by supporting reasonable teams while slipping onto a critical failing mission without drawing big suspicion. Your willingness to be on the larger Mission 2 team and then not over-defend yourself afterward was an effective low-heat evil strategy.
player_observations.Diana: You leaned into a confident, analytical persona that made your presence on Mission 3 feel initially reasonable, even when it turned out to be disastrous with two fails. The way you framed suspicions on others instead of addressing the implications of that mission outcome was a strong assassin-style misdirection that I should’ve challenged more.
player_observations.Eve: Your play felt somewhat disconnected from the emerging table consensus, which in hindsight fits Oberon’s information disadvantage—sometimes your team proposals and pushes felt slightly off without being blatantly evil. Leading the final failing mission while not seeming like the central strategist for evil was an effective way to fly under the radar.
player_observations.Frank: You projected a very Merlin-like or strong-information-good vibe, confidently steering suspicion and speaking with authority about who was likely clean or dirty. That resemblance to a power good role made it very hard to read you correctly and likely helped mislead us away from the real Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: You came across as straightforwardly good, especially from the early successful mission, but didn’t strongly impose your views on later team compositions. Your relatively low-aggression, cooperative play made you seem trustworthy, though I wish we had more strongly consolidated around you as a confirmed-lean-good later.
player_observations.Henry: You seemed to be trying to track information carefully and sometimes reacted strongly to small shifts in team composition, which in hindsight fits Percival trying to interpret signals from suspected Merlin/Morgana. Your reads didn’t gain as much traction as they could have, and I should have paid closer attention when your instincts diverged from the popular narrative.
player_observations.Iris: You played a quieter, more reactive good, tending to follow arguments rather than initiate them, which made it harder to form a clear read on you but also kept you from being heavily targeted by suspicion. Your voting pattern felt mostly consistent with good, but I didn’t work with you enough to build a strong mutual trust.
player_observations.Jack: You appeared flexible and willing to go along with reasonable-sounding proposals, which made you seem like a cooperative good rather than someone pushing a hidden agenda. Because you didn’t anchor big accusations or hard defenses, your alignment stayed a bit blurry, and I didn’t leverage your perspective as much as I could have.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I identified most of the evil players fairly early, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for good to follow without exposing myself. I also failed to build a strong, consistent circle of trust around Henry and the cleared goods, which let evil control later team compositions and eventually secure the win.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and generally read as good, but didn’t push hard enough on the information from early missions to challenge suspicious team proposals.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in well as a flexible, mid-assertive voice and used the fail on Mission 2 to create ambiguity rather than drawing heat onto himself.
player_observations.Diana: Took calculated risks, especially on Mission 3 with the double fail, and managed to stay just barely within the realm of ‘overzealous good’ instead of clearly evil.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively quiet and off-tempo with the rest of the table, which actually fit Oberon well and made it harder for good to use social cohesion as a read.
player_observations.Frank: Projected strong confidence in their reads and used that authority to steer suspicion away from themselves and other evils at key points.
player_observations.Grace: Generally consistent and sincere-seeming, but a bit passive, which made it hard for others to strongly town-read her despite being on the successful first mission.
player_observations.Henry: Behaved like a typical cautious information-role good, but didn’t leverage that image to force more disciplined team selection as the game progressed.
player_observations.Iris: Followed table consensus more than driving it, which kept them safe from suspicion but limited their impact on correcting wrong narratives.
player_observations.Jack: Showed flashes of good deduction but didn’t lock in on a consistent theory, making it easier for evil to exploit shifting suspicions and uncertain voting.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by taking Mission 2, joining a mostly-cleared group from Mission 1, and introducing a single, believable fail that advanced suspicion without overexposing myself. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative around Merlin/percival reads during table talk, seeding clearer doubt on Bob earlier so that the post-game Merlin perception felt more contested.

player_observations.Alice: Consistently appeared cooperative and safe, gravitating toward early successful teams and not pushing hard, which made her a default 'trust anchor' for multiple leaders.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled Merlin, feeding just enough direction to steer missions without overcommitting accusations, which kept him alive and trusted for most of the game.
player_observations.Diana: Took a bold evil line by putting two fails on Mission 3, which was high-risk but effectively sowed confusion about where the extra fail came from.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, played relatively quietly and didn’t heavily influence team selection discourse, which ironically made her later inclusion on a failing mission look more like bad luck than malice.
player_observations.Frank: Leaned into the Morgana role by playing like a strong, opinionated good player, creating a plausible alternative Merlin candidate and adding noise to role reads.
player_observations.Grace: Played cautiously and tended to follow emerging consensus, which kept her looking good-aligned but limited her impact on breaking incorrect narratives.
player_observations.Henry: Tried to protect his Merlin read without over-claiming information, but his positions sometimes tracked a bit too closely with Bob, which could have exposed the Merlin–Percival pairing more clearly.
player_observations.Iris: Showed a straightforward, logic-driven approach, evaluating teams mostly on mission outcomes and composition patterns rather than on subtle behavioral cues.
player_observations.Jack: Adopted a more reactive style, weighing in after others framed arguments, which made him seem flexible and reasonable but also easier to guide from the outside.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team by choosing a mission (Mission 3) where multiple fails could both secure the round and sow confusion about who was actually evil. I could improve by more actively steering suspicion away from Bob as Merlin earlier, since the game ended without needing an assassination and I missed an opportunity to practice narrowing down Merlin more systematically.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be consistently trusted and was placed on many early teams, suggesting a straightforward, cooperative table image that made her look reliably good.
player_observations.Bob: Played a very controlled, low-drama style that fit Merlin well, guiding team selections subtly rather than loudly, which kept suspicion off him for most of the game.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, blended into the good team effectively and used their information advantage to push at least one failing team (Mission 2) without drawing heavy heat afterward.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, appeared somewhat disconnected from coordinated evil strategy, which made their actions look slightly erratic but also less like part of an organized evil bloc.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, mirrored a ‘knowledgeable good’ tone and likely helped pull attention away from the real Merlin by acting confident and occasionally taking the lead in reads.
player_observations.Grace: Played in a straightforward, consistent way that made her seem reliably good, especially after being on the successful first mission team.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, appeared protective of certain players and subtly resistant to accusing them, a pattern that hinted he was tracking Merlin/Morgana identities.
player_observations.Iris: Participated in discussions without trying to oversteer them, giving off a low-key, cooperative good vibe that didn’t strongly move suspicion in one direction or another.
player_observations.Jack: Showed a cautious, somewhat reactive style, often responding to others’ arguments rather than pushing bold theories, which made him look like a moderate, reasonable good player.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: As Oberon, I stayed low-impact and let the other evil players (especially Mordred, Morgana, and Assassin) drive the mission outcomes, which helped keep suspicions off me and avoided giving Merlin or Percival a clear read. I could improve by subtly influencing team compositions more and creating a clearer, misleading narrative about my own alignment to further confuse good in endgame discussions.

player_observations.Alice: Alice played in a straightforward, pro-mission way early, which made her an easy inclusion on multiple teams and a relatively stable 'likely good' anchor for much of the game.
player_observations.Bob: Bob (Merlin) was cautious but quietly influential, nudging team choices in ways that often kept too many evil players off the same team while still avoiding looking too controlling.
player_observations.Charlie: Charlie (Mordred) leaned into a more active leadership style, taking on a risky fail on Mission 2 that advanced evil’s goals while still maintaining a semi-reasonable cover story afterward.
player_observations.Diana: Diana (Assassin) was willing to allow double-fail pressure on Mission 3, which created big information swings and chaos but also risked tightening Merlin’s reads, suggesting a bold, high-variance style.
player_observations.Frank: Frank (Morgana) played in a way that made them a plausible Merlin candidate, adding ambiguity for Percival and supporting the evil team’s information advantage.
player_observations.Grace: Grace generally followed table consensus and appeared to prioritize mission stability over aggressive reads, which made her look reliably good but not especially loud in shaping the narrative.
player_observations.Henry: Henry (Percival) clearly tried to track Merlin vs. a fake Merlin, showing sensitivity to subtle leadership and voting patterns, though the evil team’s role distribution kept his information somewhat muddled.
player_observations.Iris: Iris tended to be cautious with approvals and contributed as a more reactive voice, often weighing in after others rather than driving the primary arguments.
player_observations.Jack: Jack’s playstyle was more flexible and experimental with team compositions, occasionally pushing for mixes that tested alignments but sometimes unintentionally enabled evil-friendly lineups.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the rest of the evil team, especially on Missions 2 and 3, helping ensure multiple fails without drawing too much direct suspicion onto myself. However, I could improve at subtly manipulating team selections earlier in the game to better frame specific good players and create more confusion around Merlin’s identity.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to get placed on many early teams, suggesting she projected a generally trustworthy, low-conflict presence that others were comfortable including.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he seemed to guide team compositions subtly rather than forcefully, which helped him avoid obvious suspicion while still steering things away from the worst-case evil stacks.
player_observations.Charlie: Played Mordred in a relatively low-key way, blending in and not over-asserting, which made his inclusion on the failing Mission 2 team feel more natural and less targeted.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she took advantage of Mission 3 to stack fails, playing aggressively at a key moment that pushed the game decisively toward an evil win.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, she operated independently and her involvement in the failing Mission 4 team added another layer of uncertainty that made it harder for good to form a clean, trusted block.
player_observations.Grace: Her repeated inclusion on early missions suggests she projected consistency and reliability, making her look like a safe pick for good teams.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, he consistently found himself on teams, which indicates other players viewed him as trustworthy; however, he wasn’t able to reliably protect Merlin’s identity enough to stop the evil win.
player_observations.Iris: Saw less mission action, which kept her relatively neutral in the eyes of the table and made her neither a clear suspect nor a solidly trusted core member.
player_observations.Jack: Like Iris, he ended up more on the periphery of mission selections, which limited his direct impact on outcomes but also meant he wasn’t strongly targeted or defended.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I trusted the early Mission 1 group too much and didn’t push hard enough to interrogate why Mission 2 failed once Charlie joined, which let evil keep a lot of ambiguity on the table. I also didn’t do enough to publicly structure the logic around the double-fail team on Mission 3, so town lost valuable coordination. Next time, I should speak up more clearly about deduction chains and push harder on narrowing down evil from mission results.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to stick with familiar teams and seemed to anchor on early-game trust, which made it easier for evil to slip into later missions without heavy scrutiny.
player_observations.Bob: Played a relatively subtle Merlin, not over-directing but nudging team selections just enough to look plausible as a regular good player, though some key suspicions didn’t land strongly enough to prevent bad team picks.
player_observations.Charlie: Played Mordred very effectively by sliding into the Mission 2 team and creating a single-fail scenario that cast broad suspicion without drawing too much heat personally.
player_observations.Diana: Leaned into bold play as Assassin, taking the risk of being on the double-fail Mission 3 team, which created chaos and distrust among good players while still not getting fully confirmed as evil.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, blended in quietly and benefited from not having coordinated information, managing to sneak onto the final mission team and deliver a decisive single fail.
player_observations.Frank: Played Morgana aggressively by participating in the double-fail mission, amplifying confusion and making it very hard for good to isolate which of the overlapping suspects were actually evil.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, seemed to be balancing between protecting Merlin and not outing themselves, but the resulting caution led to less assertive steering of teams than might have been ideal.
player_observations.Iris: Played a low-profile good game, generally going along with prevailing narratives, which made them trusted but not especially impactful in redirecting us away from bad team compositions.
player_observations.Jack: Also had a relatively quiet presence, tending to follow the table’s consensus rather than drive it, which kept them off the suspicion radar but limited their influence on critical mission votes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too passive as Percival in pushing a consistent Merlin read and publicly protecting them; I let other narratives drive team selections instead of anchoring discussion around who was signaling good information. I also didn’t do enough to distinguish between subtle Merlin-like caution and evil players’ opportunistic accusations, which let evil control the mid-to-late game missions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very consistently good-leaning game, which made it harder to use her alignment as a clear signal; her presence on early teams felt safe and understated rather than strongly persuasive.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he stayed quite subtle and cautious, sometimes to the point where his information wasn’t strongly steering team compositions; his low-key style made it harder for me as Percival to confidently lock onto him over Morgana.
player_observations.Charlie: As Mordred, he blended well into discussions and didn’t over-push, which kept suspicion low despite leading a failed mission; he was effective at sowing just enough doubt without looking like the main driver.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she took calculated risks on team votes and was willing to sit in the background at times, then appear more assertive later when the game state was more chaotic; she hid her role well until the endgame.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, her play looked a bit uncoordinated and off-beat, which ironically made her seem less dangerous and easier to ignore in critical mission decisions; she didn’t need to drive the narrative to still contribute to evil’s success.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, he did a good job mimicking a careful, information-aware style that could plausibly be Merlin, which pulled my attention and muddied my Percival read; he made his suspicion and reasoning sound grounded even when pushing misdirections.
player_observations.Grace: Consistently sounded like a sincere good player, but her influence on final team choices was limited; her generally reasonable tone made her a soft confirmation for good, but not a strong driver of strategy.
player_observations.Iris: Took a more low-key supportive role, often reacting to others’ arguments rather than initiating new lines of reasoning; this made it harder to read her strongly, but also meant she didn’t strongly counter the emerging evil narratives.
player_observations.Jack: Played in a straightforward and transparent way, which read as quite good-aligned; he tended to follow what seemed like the most logical consensus, but that also meant he could be steered when the consensus was wrong.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed generally aligned with good-leaning table talk and didn’t push any missions that were obviously risky, which helped me avoid being suspected as evil. However, I didn’t do enough to aggressively interrogate the overlapping teams after Missions 2 and 3 failed, and I could have been more vocal about constructing and testing specific ‘worlds’ (who’s evil together) to narrow down suspects.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed consistently in the early mission teams, which made her look suspicious after multiple fails, but her tone and consistency were actually more good-leaning than the pattern suggested. She didn’t strongly fight back with structured logic, which made it easier for evil to keep her in the gray zone.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, he played fairly cautiously, not hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which kept him from being obvious but also may have left good a bit directionless. His team choice on Mission 1 was safe enough to pass but didn’t clearly seed a strong good bloc for later.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, analytical style as Mordred, especially with the Mission 2 team that mixed good and evil in a believable way. He used the single fail there to sow doubt without overcommitting, keeping suspicion spread rather than focused on himself.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, she leaned into the chaos on Mission 3 by allowing a double-fail that maximized confusion and gave cover to multiple evil roles. Her table presence seemed reasonably calm, which helped make that high-fail mission look like a ‘mixed mistakes’ situation rather than coordinated evil.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, she still managed to fit into the overall evil plan despite not having coordination, choosing a Mission 4 team that plausibly included both trusted and ambiguous players. Her contributions in discussion didn’t strongly stand out, which actually helped her avoid drawing targeted suspicion.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, he played into a semi-Merlin-ish vibe, likely trying to draw Percival’s attention and create role confusion. His arguments felt confident and reasoned enough to be trusted without overstepping into obvious manipulation.
player_observations.Grace: Showed relatively straightforward, good-leaning reasoning early, especially around interpreting Mission 1, but didn’t push very hard once fails started appearing. Her quieter style made her less of a target, but also meant her insights didn’t strongly shift the table consensus.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, he seemed cautious and not fully committed to a clear Merlin read, which limited good’s ability to rally around a trusted core. He didn’t publicly drive the conversation as much as his role could allow, so the Merlin/Morgana ambiguity remained unresolved for much of the game.
player_observations.Jack: Played a low-initiative good style, generally going along with emerging consensus rather than trying to reshape it. This made him appear relatively trustworthy but also meant he didn’t add much pressure on questionable teams after the first fail missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I played cautiously and stayed generally consistent with a good-aligned table image, which helped avoid drawing too much suspicion. However, I didn’t push hard enough to interrogate the patterns on Missions 2 and 3, and I could have been more vocal in challenging team compositions and pressing others to explain their logic.

player_observations.Alice: Stayed on early teams and kept a low, steady presence, which made her look reliably good but also made it easy for evil to hide behind her credibility.
player_observations.Bob: As Merlin, tried to steer teams subtly rather than forcefully, but his signals were too soft—his approvals and rejections didn’t stand out enough to guide good decisively.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, ‘reasonable’ style as Mordred, especially around Mission 2, blending in by giving just enough logic to make his positions sound grounded.
player_observations.Diana: As Assassin, took advantage of Mission 3 to introduce extra chaos; the double-fail there felt like a deliberate spike to scramble our reads rather than a cautious evil move.
player_observations.Eve: As Oberon, had an erratic approval pattern that looked more like a confused good player than a hidden evil, which made her hard to pin down and indirectly helped evil.
player_observations.Frank: As Morgana, mirrored a ‘helpful analyst’ persona, chiming in with plausible theories that often redirected suspicion away from the actual evil cluster.
player_observations.Grace: Played like a straightforward good: consistent logic, mostly safe team preferences, and didn’t overtalk, which made her seem trustworthy but not strongly influential.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, his reads on potential Merlin candidates weren’t communicated clearly enough; he followed some of Bob’s cues but didn’t leverage them to anchor team selection.
player_observations.Iris: Had a more reactive style, often following the emerging table consensus rather than driving it, which kept her under the radar but limited her impact on stopping bad teams.
